Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tempo and Mode of Diversification In Vertebrates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists have long sought explanations for why some groups of species on Earth are so much more diverse than others. This project will study the way that new species have formed and changed across different vertebrate groups throughout the history of life. New statistical methods will be developed to measure rates of speciation, extinction, and trait change across the jawed vertebrates, a large group of animals that includes fishes, mammals, birds, reptiles, and amphibians. Using new information obtained from NSF's Assembling the Tree of Life program, the project will identify groups with unusually high diversity and test potential explanations for these "evolutionary explosions."

This project will investigate the forces influencing evolutionary change over the past 500 million years of vertebrate history. Describing evolution at this scale will give us a broader understanding of life over time in general, and will be of great interest to many scientific fields. A number of educational outreach activities will be conducted with this grant, including interactions with a local science center, involvement of regional public schools, and coordination of a workshop for graduate students from around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this research were 1) to develop new statistical methods that were especially well-suited to analyzing large evolutionary trees and 2) to use those methods to understand major features of biodiversity in living groups. As part of this research, we tested the idea that the age of a group predicts the number of species within it such that the most species rich groups on the planet (e.g. beetles, flowering plants) are also the oldest. Surprisingly we found no relationship between time and diversity, suggesting that competition with other groups and other kinds of ecological interactions are responsible for species richness patterns in living groups. 

We developed new methods to test whether the tendency of a lineage to evolve new forms is tied to the rate at which that lineage speciates. We found strong evidence for this relationship between speciation and morphological evolution across 30,000 species of fishes. Our provides the first link between two commonly observed phenomena in evolutionary biology: living fossils (including groups like the coelacanth and horseshoe crabs) and adaptive radiations (including Darwin's finches and African cichlids).

As part of this study, we examined the causes of diversity in several vertebrate groups including turtles, clownfishes and other damselfishes, and primates. Our primate studies investigated the causes of facial diversity to better understand how this group evolved the most complex and varied faces of all mammals. We found strong evidence for the role of social behavior in driving the complexity of the primate face such that the most social species tend to have evolved the most diverse and complexly patterned faces. Our work suggests that complex faces have evolved in part as tools to enhance visual and social communication.

This proposal helped train high school students, university undergraduates and graduate and postdoctoral scientists in evolutionary methods.
